awd_titl_txt: Sparse Bounds and Improving Estimates, Continuous and Discrete
awd_abstract_narration:
Averaging always smooths out, or improves, functions or data.  In the continuous case, this phenomena has been intensively studied for decades. If we average over objects in a discrete setting like the integers, or some other high dimensional lattice, the smoothing properties of the average have only recently started to be studied.  A natural object to study is the average over a discrete sphere in a five dimensional lattice. The proof that the average improves functions engages a range of deep aspects within number theory and analysis. However, resolving the natural limits for this question still seem difficult. In this project, these questions will be explored in a setting that involves both continuous and discrete phenomena.  These questions are also elementary to state, which makes them amenable for mentoring programs, from undergraduate through postdoctoral levels.  

An improving inequality in the continuous setting has been widely studied since the 1970's. However, the corresponding questions in the discrete setting have only just attracted attention. For instance, averages over the discrete sphere in the d-dimensional integers, with d at least 5, have a rich theory of improving inequalities, paralleling the much better known continuous case.  The proofs however involve complications arising from multi-frequency analysis, as well as fine estimates on Kloosterman sums. There is a richer theory, the outlines of which are appearing, giving a sharp range of inequalities for some arithmetic varieties.  This subject also allows for the proof of certain sparse bounds. The latter are scale-free versions of the improving inequalities. A sparse bound immediately implies other weighted and vector valued consequences.  The latter are new in this subject. These questions reveal new aspects of these averaging operators, and require new modes of investigation, deepening the connection between harmonic analysis and number theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project supported research in areas of harmonic analysis, ergodic theory and number theory, complemented by on-going training of a next generation of STEM focused workforce.  An attractive result obtained concerns an extension of the famous result of Vinogradov to a specialized setting in the Gaussian integers. The latter are the integers in the complex plane. They have notions of addition, products, being even, odd and of primality.   Draw any sector anchored at the origin.  A large enough odd integer, inside the sector but not very close to the boundary, is the sum of three primes which are also in the sector.  


In parallel with the ongoing research efforts on a range of topics, the PI has a program to train students at all levels. The PI's grant supported three students who finished their degrees in the time frame of this grant. They include one woman, and a Black man. All three are in postdoctoral positions, continuing their growth in the profession.  A fourth student will finish next year. A first year graduate student has already produced one chapter of their thesis, based on a suggestion of the PI.  Several postdoctoral fellows have been coauthors, including a woman now in a tenure track position in Louisiana.  The PI will mentor one to two postdoctoral fellows starting in the Fall, and teach a special topics course on his research.  

The PI is also guiding a program that provides Georgia Tech courses, in distance format, to High School students across Georgia. This is done through two programs, the first well established program supplements the secondary education of students who have already completed all their mathematics. They are enrolled in Linear Algebra and Vector Calculus. One thousand students will be in this program in the Fall term. They are the most well qualified students in the state. The opportunity provided by this program allows these students to gain high quality mathematics instruction while still in High School. A second program, just in its pilot year, targets students at the PreCalculus level, with  second course in Physics. The need for this program is even more significant than our established program. We are optimistic it can have a very large impact across the State.
